subject: Add Content-Security-Policy(CSP) Level2 Directives
commitMessage:
Add Content-Security-Policy(CSP) Level2 Directives

Content Security Policy Level2 directives as below,
form-action set to 'none'-No form-submissions to external websites.
frame-ancestors set to 'none' -Preventing framing attacks
(clickjacking, cross-site leaks)
plugin-types set to 'none' -Plugins are not allowed
base-uri set to 'none' -protect against classical stored,reflected,
and some of the DOM XSS attacks.

More Information
<https://cheatsheetseries.owasp.org/cheatsheets/
Content_Security_Policy_Cheat_Sheet.html>

Tested :
Checked the CSP level directives in Chrome/Firefox/Safari Browsers,
webui and webui-vue.

Change-Id: Id823958469fdbb02259fcc24c4e91789c65eec33
Signed-off-by: Basheer Ahmed Muddebihal <basheerx.muddebihal@intel.com>

Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as 09e7afdc5aad573dbdb21b523893f2ac02477686 by Ed Tanous

Hi Basheer,
Thanks for the commit. 

Delete since already have a signed-off below.
Will remove
I suspect this is supposed to be your summary ? Can you remove the indent?
will remove in next patch

Can you remove the indents?
We follow https://chris.beams.io/posts/git-commit/ for commit msgs.
Will remove

Can you please test the other common browsers (firefox and safari) as well as test that the existing webuis (phosphor-webui and webui-vue) load properly?

Just loading up the initial page should be plenty.  We tend to have weird behaviors around this kind of thing and websockets, so I want to make sure that's not broken.
to further clarify.... load up the initial page with the debug network tab open and ensure there aren't any errors on content loading, and no warnings or errors on the console tab.

BMCWEB currently supports Content-Security-Policy(CSP) Level 1,as part of the Security Development Lifecycle guidelines, Added the CSP level 2 directives, followed recommendations https://content-security-policy.com/ and https://www.w3.org/TR/CSP2/.     

Tested with other browsers(firefox and Safari),webui, webui-vue loading pages successfully.

Can you please walk through these headers (in your commit message) and list why they're here.  Feel free to link to supporting documentation where it makes sense, but we need a much better statement for why OpenBMC needs these.  Also, some of them look wrong to me, but your commit message doesn't give me enough detail about what you're trying to accomplish to know how to help you.

If things have a default behavior (like report-uri or frame-ancestors), please don't explicitly set them to the default behavior.  We'd rather take the browsers lead on those.

form-action looks incorrect.  I wouldn't expect any form actions in the current webui code (all is done via xhr js).
plugin-types looks wrong, I can't imagine where we'd have PDF anywhere.

Thanks Ed Tanous for review comments.
BMCWEB currently supports Content-Security-Policy(CSP) Level 1,as part of the Security Development Lifecycle guidelines, Added the CSP level 2 directives, followed recommendations from the following website https://content-security-policy.com/ and https://www.w3.org/TR/CSP2/.     

form-action 'self' , self Allows loading resources from the same origin (same scheme, host and port).

yes you are right, changed plug-in set to none  
Need to set frame-ancestors 'none' to avoid clickjacking ( https://report-uri.com/solutions/clickjacking_protection )
report-uri set to none as it is deprecated in level 3,

Lots of typos, and whitespace issues.  Please proofread your commit messages before pushing them.

Also, SDLC is not a public spec.  Please look through the existing guidelines documents we use (OWASP, ect) and find rooting for these changes.  OpenBMC is not a security authority, and we follow others (Mozilla and OWASP primarily) lead on web security.
Will Correct it
report-uri makes no sense when we don't have CSP reporting implemented.  This would be a separate feature, and not just a header change, for the moment, this is the default, so it can be removed.
Will remove it as it needs separate implementation
Does owasp recommend these?  that's the authority we generally use.  We can certainly take other guidance, but I'd like to avoid taking multiple guidance's.

Checked the OWASP it also refers to w3c specification 
https://owasp.org/www-community/controls/Content_Security_Policy
Not all comments addressed.
report-uri is removed as it is separate implementation

Considering we have no children, and have no forms, these are arguably less secure than default-src 'none'

Please in your commit message talk through why each of these is needed, and point to the relevant documentation.

The default-src doesn't apply for form-action: 
"default-src fallback	No. Not setting this allows anything"
(https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/Content-Security-Policy/form-action). 
I am no expert here, but aren't forms used when uploading files (certificates and FW update)? I also see an <input> element in ModelUser.vue
Added information why these directives are added in Commit message, and also added the link for OWASP documentation,  followed best practices guidelines https://owasp.org/www-project-secure-headers/

> The default-src doesn't apply for form-action: 

Fair point on that;  I would assume it does apply to child-src, so that's incorrect.

> I am no expert here, but aren't forms used when uploading files

While we use forms, so far as I'm aware, we don't use form actions, we use javascript onclick handlers (someone correct me if I'm wrong), which I would assume wouldn't be effected by CSP.

With that said, if the current UI can't run with "form-action 'none'", then I'm ok with this, but I suspect it should.
Please remove.  This doesn't need to go inline unless there's a strange case.
removed the line
Please comment on why default-src: none isn't effective here (I expect it is, and this header is unneeded).
Agreed with you however as part of CSP security level2 need to initialize to default value for all directives. Setting 'self' for future enhancements.

"future enhancements" is cryptic and unhelpful in the context of this patchset.  Once those enhancements come, feel free to push a patch to add child-src, but for the moment, there's no reason it's needed.
Agreed, removed the child-src
Please test with form-action 'none' and report your findings.  I don't believe the UI uses form actions anywhere (although I'm happy to be wrong).

you are correct, tested BMCWEB with form-action set to 'none' does not have any affect on firmware upgrade and User unlocking after failures of user login forms. Also need to understand why we need to need not set to 'self' is there any reason?

You should look into "principle of least privilege"

Basically, if the application doesn't explicitly need s privilege to function, it should be set to the most restricted values.
Set to none

Considering there's still whitespace violations, no.... you haven't resolved all the comments.  I shouldn't have to mention this twice.  (3 times if you count telling you that missed comments the first time around).
Figured out it is the Issue with web editor, will configure correctly will not have issues next time onwards
Glad you figured it out;
Resolved all white spaces
Please test better than this.  Verifying the header got attached is not an effective test.  Please verify both UIs still boot and function as designed, especially surrounding firmware update.
Tested on the both UIs, Upgrading the Firmware , and User lockout Issues,  Results are successful
Tests are passed on both UI

As was pointed out previously, please remove this line;  This setting is less secure than what was there previously.  If you find a feature that requires this, please add it separately, while pointing to the feature that requires it.
As we discussed (and as you tested) form-action 'none' is more restrictive here.
